Company. Big powerful change. Wet bright bills for next week. _Fun on	 214.74270071641956
the Bristol_. Martin Cunningham could work a pass for the Gaiety. Have	 65.48915208420215
to stand a drink or two. As broad as it’s long.	 142.55828721262935
He’s coming in the afternoon. Her songs.	 183.670815432431
Plasto’s. Sir Philip Crampton’s memorial fountain bust. Who was he?	 57.45634861758205
—How do you do? Martin Cunningham said, raising his palm to his brow in	 23.763967532362184
salute.	 8592.805663192214
—He doesn’t see us, Mr Power said. Yes, he does. How do you do?	 24.0575971962632
—Who? Mr Dedalus asked.	 62.786283096183375
—Blazes Boylan, Mr Power said. There he is airing his quiff.	 31.48062921503386
Just that moment I was thinking.	 88.68788123876085
Mr Dedalus bent across to salute. From the door of the Red Bank the	 25.070226113153282
white disc of a straw hat flashed reply: spruce figure: passed.	 83.14395561667523
Mr Bloom reviewed the nails of his left hand, then those of his right	 59.80397540947773
hand. The nails, yes. Is there anything more in him that they she sees?	 212.83857933758478
Fascination. Worst man in Dublin. That keeps him alive. They sometimes	 120.29373215665314
feel what a person is. Instinct. But a type like that. My nails. I am	 92.94221028735049
just looking at them: well pared. And after: thinking alone. Body	 176.85154509795188
getting a bit softy. I would notice that: from remembering. What causes	 81.65252391622246
that? I suppose the skin can’t contract quickly enough when the flesh	 159.14254967154503
falls off. But the shape is there. The shape is there still. Shoulders.	 154.07207019714912
Hips. Plump. Night of the dance dressing. Shift stuck between the	 183.3245385163482
cheeks behind.	 1547.3599646106084
He clasped his hands between his knees and, satisfied, sent his vacant	 59.43957825051727
glance over their faces.	 134.23096012724596
Mr Power asked:	 27.87304281426437
—How is the concert tour getting on, Bloom?	 62.89016637348419
—O, very well, Mr Bloom said. I hear great accounts of it. It’s a good	 35.635731003929884
idea, you see...	 112.2842298537208
—Are you going yourself?	 47.61332814994567
—Well no, Mr Bloom said. In point of fact I have to go down to the	 26.839039176430465
county Clare on some private business. You see the idea is to tour the	 96.56332331842347
chief towns. What you lose on one you can make up on the other.	 104.28868159312091
—Quite so, Martin Cunningham said. Mary Anderson is up there now.	 82.37466288815672
Have you good artists?	 55.58770960507547
—Louis Werner is touring her, Mr Bloom said. O yes, we’ll have all	 45.69833218721132
topnobbers. J. C. Doyle and John MacCormack I hope and. The best, in	 72.39723341446053
fact.	 16104.56723004959
—And _Madame_, Mr Power said smiling. Last but not least.	 82.48372483323337
Mr Bloom unclasped his hands in a gesture of soft politeness and	 25.09207218762419
clasped them. Smith O’Brien. Someone has laid a bunch of flowers there.	 116.4854342559291
Woman. Must be his deathday. For many happy returns. The carriage	 107.9458678117395
wheeling by Farrell’s statue united noiselessly their unresisting	 37.78682947314774
knees.	 9129.572798767445
Oot: a dullgarbed old man from the curbstone tendered his wares, his	 29.745789800007135
mouth opening: oot.	 132.22835517893367
—Four bootlaces for a penny.	 51.95194990165025
Wonder why he was struck off the rolls. Had his office in Hume street.	 68.25562224377612
Same house as Molly’s namesake, Tweedy, crown solicitor for Waterford.	 131.42321615278345
Has that silk hat ever since. Relics of old decency. Mourning too.	 108.66814839634417
Terrible comedown, poor wretch! Kicked about like snuff at a wake.	 169.55672249222545
O’Callaghan on his last legs.	 53.173869560548056
And _Madame_. Twenty past eleven. Up. Mrs Fleming is in to clean. Doing	 179.4576342706898
her hair, humming: _voglio e non vorrei_. No: _vorrei e non_. Looking	 36.82451398047651
at the tips of her hairs to see if they are split. _Mi trema un poco	 25.739318392279163
il_. Beautiful on that _tre_ her voice is: weeping tone. A thrush. A	 106.59351538973532
throstle. There is a word throstle that expresses that.	 30.669362209015443
His eyes passed lightly over Mr Power’s goodlooking face. Greyish over	 67.10706019617592
the ears. _Madame_: smiling. I smiled back. A smile goes a long way.	 139.5872892927687
Only politeness perhaps. Nice fellow. Who knows is that true about the	 86.0620799510785
woman he keeps? Not pleasant for the wife. Yet they say, who was it	 67.42347347202694
told me, there is no carnal. You would imagine that would get played	 69.60712861588263
out pretty quick. Yes, it was Crofton met him one evening bringing her	 104.07660931760235
a pound of rumpsteak. What is this she was? Barmaid in Jury’s. Or the	 34.18572059372957
Moira, was it?	 30.050561419702973
They passed under the hugecloaked Liberator’s form.	 37.73410204703765
Martin Cunningham nudged Mr Power.	 36.53072975720075
—Of the tribe of Reuben, he said.	 31.754308201157617
A tall blackbearded figure, bent on a stick, stumping round the corner	 80.24337235534297
of Elvery’s Elephant house, showed them a curved hand open on his	 29.268402081145783
spine.	 4.608171674364364
—In all his pristine beauty, Mr Power said.	 46.83455781609646
Mr Dedalus looked after the stumping figure and said mildly:	 40.1479725858518
—The devil break the hasp of your back!	 46.64142006560206
Mr Power, collapsing in laughter, shaded his face from the window as	 46.23570420566018
the carriage passed Gray’s statue.	 148.15866237529764
—We have all been there, Martin Cunningham said broadly.	 36.503057710885024
His eyes met Mr Bloom’s eyes. He caressed his beard, adding:	 43.378322225976866
—Well, nearly all of us.	 189.89598369600702
Mr Bloom began to speak with sudden eagerness to his companions’ faces.	 33.64486116341558
—That’s an awfully good one that’s going the rounds about Reuben J and	 75.83758815034082
the son.	 86.79687478911175
—About the boatman? Mr Power asked.	 45.693035016524654
—Yes. Isn’t it awfully good?	 42.92470908711456
—What is that? Mr Dedalus asked. I didn’t hear it.	 18.87125711027964
—There was a girl in the case, Mr Bloom began, and he determined to	 25.52756063211939
send him to the Isle of Man out of harm’s way but when they were	 40.543469102232116
both.....	 4928.0374648439
—What? Mr Dedalus asked. That confirmed bloody hobbledehoy is it?	 48.80284128106837
—Yes, Mr Bloom said. They were both on the way to the boat and he tried	 35.245275661537036
to drown.....	 29.86908918584726
—Drown Barabbas! Mr Dedalus cried. I wish to Christ he did!	 46.32811688834981
Mr Power sent a long laugh down his shaded nostrils.	 61.21799226551378
—No, Mr Bloom said, the son himself.....	 36.3239586926685
Martin Cunningham thwarted his speech rudely:	 39.888693869918455
—Reuben J and the son were piking it down the quay next the river on	 84.80743526502171
their way to the Isle of Man boat and the young chiseller suddenly got	 74.33830204136241
loose and over the wall with him into the Liffey.	 122.13234769134336
—For God’s sake! Mr Dedalus exclaimed in fright. Is he dead?	 59.31570516510578
—Dead! Martin Cunningham cried. Not he! A boatman got a pole and fished	 80.40632900795637
him out by the slack of the breeches and he was landed up to the father	 48.81253837896719
on the quay more dead than alive. Half the town was there.	 132.92208126045134
—Yes, Mr Bloom said. But the funny part is.....	 38.25439292944292
—And Reuben J, Martin Cunningham said, gave the boatman a florin for	 50.074461772576576
saving his son’s life.	 43.87626223674189
A stifled sigh came from under Mr Power’s hand.	 64.6010611636096
—O, he did, Martin Cunningham affirmed. Like a hero. A silver florin.	 63.40764300373881
—Isn’t it awfully good? Mr Bloom said eagerly.	 34.184380220900934
—One and eightpence too much, Mr Dedalus said drily.	 15.526225991162928
Mr Power’s choked laugh burst quietly in the carriage.	 58.573309542307605
Nelson’s pillar.	 127.6959148256438
—Eight plums a penny! Eight for a penny!	 82.29785047485586
—We had better look a little serious, Martin Cunningham said.	 32.35484967358666
Mr Dedalus sighed.	 23.061634729910462
—Ah then indeed, he said, poor little Paddy wouldn’t grudge us a laugh.	 71.47456920007458
Many a good one he told himself.	 72.886196537493
—The Lord forgive me! Mr Power said, wiping his wet eyes with his	 34.567899055233134
fingers. Poor Paddy! I little thought a week ago when I saw him last	 119.66169074775658
and he was in his usual health that I’d be driving after him like this.	 71.94193681823154
He’s gone from us.	 54.158664829791924
—As decent a little man as ever wore a hat, Mr Dedalus said. He went	 61.50445630658569
very suddenly.	 1061.5372306652846
—Breakdown, Martin Cunningham said. Heart.	 38.56265715440742
He tapped his chest sadly.	 71.70378390789196
Blazing face: redhot. Too much John Barleycorn. Cure for a red nose.	 54.19519532549536
Drink like the devil till it turns adelite. A lot of money he spent	 120.31266997716226
colouring it.	 31.839927380285154
Mr Power gazed at the passing houses with rueful apprehension.	 38.56686080739052
—He had a sudden death, poor fellow, he said.	 82.55226045393947
—The best death, Mr Bloom said.	 23.349331312473634
Their wide open eyes looked at him.	 200.5888159110981
—No suffering, he said. A moment and all is over. Like dying in sleep.	 90.91667019146726
No-one spoke.	 237.46640597130647
Dead side of the street this. Dull business by day, land agents,	 103.00727062662132
temperance hotel, Falconer’s railway guide, civil service college,	 381.28038907735686
Gill’s, catholic club, the industrious blind. Why? Some reason. Sun or	 255.10794211672672
wind. At night too. Chummies and slaveys. Under the patronage of the	 28.265365574080086
late Father Mathew. Foundation stone for Parnell. Breakdown. Heart.	 293.19700842964977
White horses with white frontlet plumes came round the Rotunda corner,	 50.06424608328542
galloping. A tiny coffin flashed by. In a hurry to bury. A mourning	 82.54565778616612
coach. Unmarried. Black for the married. Piebald for bachelors. Dun for	 79.33257877557296
a nun.	 205.4434371554861
—Sad, Martin Cunningham said. A child.	 45.25621450533669
A dwarf’s face, mauve and wrinkled like little Rudy’s was. Dwarf’s	 57.90723965546052
body, weak as putty, in a whitelined deal box. Burial friendly society	 56.127923405245134
pays. Penny a week for a sod of turf. Our. Little. Beggar. Baby. Meant	 89.52393258692285
nothing. Mistake of nature. If it’s healthy it’s from the mother. If	 120.34632430801265
not from the man. Better luck next time.	 103.35860412721138
—Poor little thing, Mr Dedalus said. It’s well out of it.	 38.676167876946316
The carriage climbed more slowly the hill of Rutland square. Rattle his	 63.13915842279259
bones. Over the stones. Only a pauper. Nobody owns.	 106.28982793748429
—In the midst of life, Martin Cunningham said.	 20.005774671891825
—But the worst of all, Mr Power said, is the man who takes his own	 43.75848662814001
life.	 1040.235324093293
Martin Cunningham drew out his watch briskly, coughed and put it back.	 30.662347210140297
—The greatest disgrace to have in the family, Mr Power added.	 38.82710925008475
—Temporary insanity, of course, Martin Cunningham said decisively. We	 12.415222846535022
must take a charitable view of it.	 48.061436272250674
—They say a man who does it is a coward, Mr Dedalus said.	 22.49576314444096
—It is not for us to judge, Martin Cunningham said.	 37.516733337671035
Mr Bloom, about to speak, closed his lips again. Martin Cunningham’s	 105.6333563960092
large eyes. Looking away now. Sympathetic human man he is. Intelligent.	 151.76876700632585
Like Shakespeare’s face. Always a good word to say. They have no mercy	 59.24066533794082
on that here or infanticide. Refuse christian burial. They used to	 84.3460699454353
drive a stake of wood through his heart in the grave. As if it wasn’t	 77.22307052020578
broken already. Yet sometimes they repent too late. Found in the	 98.87276172535836
riverbed clutching rushes. He looked at me. And that awful drunkard of	 59.50622029686984
a wife of his. Setting up house for her time after time and then	 130.61725809624738
pawning the furniture on him every Saturday almost. Leading him the	 34.13175457519985
life of the damned. Wear the heart out of a stone, that. Monday	 96.21044832857852
morning. Start afresh. Shoulder to the wheel. Lord, she must have	 104.91452793816788
looked a sight that night Dedalus told me he was in there. Drunk about	 137.03311501354472
the place and capering with Martin’s umbrella.	 56.785873545362364
And they call me the jewel of Asia,	 20.767413264947162
Of Asia,	 19.14104210176948
The geisha.	 7.77559996992721
He looked away from me. He knows. Rattle his bones.	 51.459687087694846
That afternoon of the inquest. The redlabelled bottle on the table. The	 44.0343903115179
room in the hotel with hunting pictures. Stuffy it was. Sunlight	 123.54223809883294
through the slats of the Venetian blind. The coroner’s sunlit ears, big	 32.961341891182705
and hairy. Boots giving evidence. Thought he was asleep first. Then saw	 170.5446427317929
like yellow streaks on his face. Had slipped down to the foot of the	 33.22427234541316
bed. Verdict: overdose. Death by misadventure. The letter. For my son	 93.34326635232856
Leopold.	 2126.232617436416
No more pain. Wake no more. Nobody owns.	 50.80866968510555
The carriage rattled swiftly along Blessington street. Over the stones.	 44.32371306027631
—We are going the pace, I think, Martin Cunningham said.	 43.91969267010281
—God grant he doesn’t upset us on the road, Mr Power said.	 54.129523684108534
—I hope not, Martin Cunningham said. That will be a great race tomorrow	 37.77098030564124
in Germany. The Gordon Bennett.	 50.922441598620125
—Yes, by Jove, Mr Dedalus said. That will be worth seeing, faith.	 63.24700078728511
As they turned into Berkeley street a streetorgan near the Basin sent	 46.865833952641445
over and after them a rollicking rattling song of the halls. Has	 100.50250206037053
anybody here seen Kelly? Kay ee double ell wy. Dead March from _Saul._	 103.72641613509145
He’s as bad as old Antonio. He left me on my ownio. Pirouette! The	 37.85442664111699
_Mater Misericordiae_. Eccles street. My house down there. Big place.	 244.28125993352356
Ward for incurables there. Very encouraging. Our Lady’s Hospice for the	 62.88586895522254
dying. Deadhouse handy underneath. Where old Mrs Riordan died. They	 159.90584736905348
look terrible the women. Her feeding cup and rubbing her mouth with the	 134.3822718546829
spoon. Then the screen round her bed for her to die. Nice young student	 155.88475183443492
that was dressed that bite the bee gave me. He’s gone over to the	 68.50909676736674
lying-in hospital they told me. From one extreme to the other.	 57.6528752539691
The carriage galloped round a corner: stopped.	 54.04740227666321
—What’s wrong now?	 64.1037557752169
A divided drove of branded cattle passed the windows, lowing, slouching	 99.25907180844813
by on padded hoofs, whisking their tails slowly on their clotted bony	 99.03350006988926
croups. Outside them and through them ran raddled sheep bleating their	 173.08375101389157
fear.	 6342.865771034647
—Emigrants, Mr Power said.	 14.279043527561011
—Huuuh! the drover’s voice cried, his switch sounding on their flanks.	 19.791150103063003
Huuuh! out of that!	 22.095078525936163
Thursday, of course. Tomorrow is killing day. Springers. Cuffe sold	 89.91811081816498
them about twentyseven quid each. For Liverpool probably. Roastbeef for	 185.33851250444272
old England. They buy up all the juicy ones. And then the fifth quarter	 58.05291272065896
lost: all that raw stuff, hide, hair, horns. Comes to a big thing in a	 110.35643566544807
year. Dead meat trade. Byproducts of the slaughterhouses for tanneries,	 76.33660363595392
soap, margarine. Wonder if that dodge works now getting dicky meat off	 300.2743554174692
the train at Clonsilla.	 38.825934376913374
The carriage moved on through the drove.	 67.37821468516498
—I can’t make out why the corporation doesn’t run a tramline from the	 79.124898341708
parkgate to the quays, Mr Bloom said. All those animals could be taken	 26.918501884778156
in trucks down to the boats.	 23.34509660797074
—Instead of blocking up the thoroughfare, Martin Cunningham said. Quite	 63.712125793807104
right. They ought to.	 68.99623847349102
—Yes, Mr Bloom said, and another thing I often thought, is to have	 29.228698976919436
municipal funeral trams like they have in Milan, you know. Run the line	 128.22668414430808
out to the cemetery gates and have special trams, hearse and carriage	 97.66049139742894
and all. Don’t you see what I mean?	 39.37600232964087
—O, that be damned for a story, Mr Dedalus said. Pullman car and saloon	 69.92249938393827
diningroom.	 4.608171674364364
—A poor lookout for Corny, Mr Power added.	 72.39127729770448
—Why? Mr Bloom asked, turning to Mr Dedalus. Wouldn’t it be more decent	 59.20595238124554
than galloping two abreast?	 97.24783435124931
—Well, there’s something in that, Mr Dedalus granted.	 67.67538973086079
—And, Martin Cunningham said, we wouldn’t have scenes like that when	 37.42207308235041
the hearse capsized round Dunphy’s and upset the coffin on to the road.	 24.64189895581487
—That was terrible, Mr Power’s shocked face said, and the corpse fell	 106.75570261909205
about the road. Terrible!	 126.17099433511135
—First round Dunphy’s, Mr Dedalus said, nodding. Gordon Bennett cup.	 102.36337143761973
—Praises be to God! Martin Cunningham said piously.	 34.817921065372786
Bom! Upset. A coffin bumped out on to the road. Burst open. Paddy	 33.91617519987134
Dignam shot out and rolling over stiff in the dust in a brown habit too	 93.6140572365764
large for him. Red face: grey now. Mouth fallen open. Asking what’s up	 286.8114838060302
now. Quite right to close it. Looks horrid open. Then the insides	 89.59089421708146
decompose quickly. Much better to close up all the orifices. Yes, also.	 83.81837989231173
With wax. The sphincter loose. Seal up all.	 155.68821110928826
—Dunphy’s, Mr Power announced as the carriage turned right.	 86.8008743226459
Dunphy’s corner. Mourning coaches drawn up, drowning their grief. A	 116.33164591224008
pause by the wayside. Tiptop position for a pub. Expect we’ll pull up	 52.09150502050475
here on the way back to drink his health. Pass round the consolation.	 66.12936988872025
Elixir of life.	 23.724409079747204
But suppose now it did happen. Would he bleed if a nail say cut him in	 93.67062156486979
the knocking about? He would and he wouldn’t, I suppose. Depends on	 132.3534262637892
where. The circulation stops. Still some might ooze out of an artery.	 62.91289654488453
It would be better to bury them in red: a dark red.	 118.36405245080181
In silence they drove along Phibsborough road. An empty hearse trotted	 89.06276135282654
by, coming from the cemetery: looks relieved.	 104.14189990360103
Crossguns bridge: the royal canal.	 40.40405163999081
Water rushed roaring through the sluices. A man stood on his dropping	 80.37483743315344
barge, between clamps of turf. On the towpath by the lock a	 49.97219984221931
slacktethered horse. Aboard of the _Bugabu._	 22.812085153018238
Their eyes watched him. On the slow weedy waterway he had floated on	 33.53086994392177
his raft coastward over Ireland drawn by a haulage rope past beds of	 58.587554443768276
reeds, over slime, mudchoked bottles, carrion dogs. Athlone, Mullingar,	 114.28306986764804
Moyvalley, I could make a walking tour to see Milly by the canal. Or	 37.65578371168829
cycle down. Hire some old crock, safety. Wren had one the other day at	 62.617473475811245
the auction but a lady’s. Developing waterways. James M’Cann’s hobby to	 52.995409221518734
row me o’er the ferry. Cheaper transit. By easy stages. Houseboats.	 32.93710155872399
Camping out. Also hearses. To heaven by water. Perhaps I will without	 87.87239982224258
writing. Come as a surprise, Leixlip, Clonsilla. Dropping down lock by	 101.86155201769063
lock to Dublin. With turf from the midland bogs. Salute. He lifted his	 70.69743288516834
brown straw hat, saluting Paddy Dignam.	 50.912648216593645
They drove on past Brian Boroimhe house. Near it now.	 72.07892929615649
—I wonder how is our friend Fogarty getting on, Mr Power said.	 29.032369222805848
—Better ask Tom Kernan, Mr Dedalus said.	 21.46488624358062
—How is that? Martin Cunningham said. Left him weeping, I suppose?	 53.45519656543702
—Though lost to sight, Mr Dedalus said, to memory dear.	 124.90367149670028
The carriage steered left for Finglas road.	 92.777009883669
The stonecutter’s yard on the right. Last lap. Crowded on the spit of	 34.91432794514635
land silent shapes appeared, white, sorrowful, holding out calm hands,	 146.94137326336258
knelt in grief, pointing. Fragments of shapes, hewn. In white silence:	 59.65370048175523
appealing. The best obtainable. Thos. H. Dennany, monumental builder	 20.62420104137352
and sculptor.	 15.372472535691111
Passed.	 2539.7970503388506
On the curbstone before Jimmy Geary, the sexton’s, an old tramp sat,	 64.81947786038454
grumbling, emptying the dirt and stones out of his huge dustbrown	 21.135445913501066
yawning boot. After life’s journey.	 56.76361957055626
Gloomy gardens then went by: one by one: gloomy houses.	 228.97830442916154
Mr Power pointed.	 39.45696732995347
—That is where Childs was murdered, he said. The last house.	 97.44665314595834
—So it is, Mr Dedalus said. A gruesome case. Seymour Bushe got him off.	 43.88671574165012
Murdered his brother. Or so they said.	 161.08228688676198
—The crown had no evidence, Mr Power said.	 54.2700765785083
—Only circumstantial, Martin Cunningham added. That’s the maxim of the	 22.662139377824857
law. Better for ninetynine guilty to escape than for one innocent	 182.69550224787722
person to be wrongfully condemned.	 85.64733504461239
They looked. Murderer’s ground. It passed darkly. Shuttered,	 96.46837640657132
tenantless, unweeded garden. Whole place gone to hell. Wrongfully	 82.56756682677678
condemned. Murder. The murderer’s image in the eye of the murdered.	 54.10470487477377
They love reading about it. Man’s head found in a garden. Her clothing	 138.14660454402346
consisted of. How she met her death. Recent outrage. The weapon used.	 90.79489822527242
Murderer is still at large. Clues. A shoelace. The body to be exhumed.	 42.674527317971425
Murder will out.	 2201.878219899999
Cramped in this carriage. She mightn’t like me to come that way without	 82.02733441290249
letting her know. Must be careful about women. Catch them once with	 133.93446098478128
their pants down. Never forgive you after. Fifteen.	 106.19379421529472
The high railings of Prospect rippled past their gaze. Dark poplars,	 42.699597341847884
rare white forms. Forms more frequent, white shapes thronged amid the	 42.98395787366053
trees, white forms and fragments streaming by mutely, sustaining vain	 50.81909818591606
gestures on the air.	 91.7547209838428
The felly harshed against the curbstone: stopped. Martin Cunningham put	 29.52580292582201
out his arm and, wrenching back the handle, shoved the door open with	 44.089110955312385
his knee. He stepped out. Mr Power and Mr Dedalus followed.	 60.667300948292834
Change that soap now. Mr Bloom’s hand unbuttoned his hip pocket swiftly	 71.27928267231486
and transferred the paperstuck soap to his inner handkerchief pocket.	 39.31323696994504
He stepped out of the carriage, replacing the newspaper his other hand	 49.057640474375084
still held.	 723.9793371365595
Paltry funeral: coach and three carriages. It’s all the same.	 58.99121073830886
Pallbearers, gold reins, requiem mass, firing a volley. Pomp of death.	 49.850599279683195
Beyond the hind carriage a hawker stood by his barrow of cakes and	 83.5864797089628
fruit. Simnel cakes those are, stuck together: cakes for the dead.	 131.06474435062987
Dogbiscuits. Who ate them? Mourners coming out.	 66.52951724037348
He followed his companions. Mr Kernan and Ned Lambert followed, Hynes	 60.89680346030537
walking after them. Corny Kelleher stood by the opened hearse and took	 78.45900356953219
out the two wreaths. He handed one to the boy.	 91.22420678217252
Where is that child’s funeral disappeared to?	 41.86472456943491
A team of horses passed from Finglas with toiling plodding tread,	 42.61870271052491
dragging through the funereal silence a creaking waggon on which lay a	 47.285149500008025
granite block. The waggoner marching at their head saluted.	 118.70156240850957
Coffin now. Got here before us, dead as he is. Horse looking round at	 164.65242541021874
it with his plume skeowways. Dull eye: collar tight on his neck,	 115.09114670736678
pressing on a bloodvessel or something. Do they know what they cart out	 32.32272250467052
here every day? Must be twenty or thirty funerals every day. Then Mount	 77.49691759983551
Jerome for the protestants. Funerals all over the world everywhere	 31.621306736198022
every minute. Shovelling them under by the cartload doublequick.	 56.35263057545538
Thousands every hour. Too many in the world.	 167.01785965730255
Mourners came out through the gates: woman and a girl. Leanjawed harpy,	 57.87612469413594
hard woman at a bargain, her bonnet awry. Girl’s face stained with dirt	 96.78216198365513
and tears, holding the woman’s arm, looking up at her for a sign to	 71.97227085871936
cry. Fish’s face, bloodless and livid.	 38.0453022424217
The mutes shouldered the coffin and bore it in through the gates. So	 52.13565308308073
much dead weight. Felt heavier myself stepping out of that bath. First	 127.73347967866238
the stiff: then the friends of the stiff. Corny Kelleher and the boy	 53.03557712612563
followed with their wreaths. Who is that beside them? Ah, the	 140.1840861285708
brother-in-law.	 6060.589310016232
All walked after.	 357.61853429157634
Martin Cunningham whispered:	 24.474909475081123
—I was in mortal agony with you talking of suicide before Bloom.	 73.41744037725202
—What? Mr Power whispered. How so?	 60.36100717572195
—His father poisoned himself, Martin Cunningham whispered. Had the	 26.872486575793626
Queen’s hotel in Ennis. You heard him say he was going to Clare.	 69.22437622278598
Anniversary.	 4.608171674364364
—O God! Mr Power whispered. First I heard of it. Poisoned himself?	 50.04109572642847
He glanced behind him to where a face with dark thinking eyes followed	 120.84305904305862
towards the cardinal’s mausoleum. Speaking.	 46.010493984214655
—Was he insured? Mr Bloom asked.	 46.02673259425287
—I believe so, Mr Kernan answered. But the policy was heavily	 98.58829641662649
mortgaged. Martin is trying to get the youngster into Artane.	 62.181539121538684
—How many children did he leave?	 40.30976981317856
—Five. Ned Lambert says he’ll try to get one of the girls into Todd’s.	 63.47574341320804
—A sad case, Mr Bloom said gently. Five young children.	 89.12911363715999
—A great blow to the poor wife, Mr Kernan added.	 72.44977265429107
—Indeed yes, Mr Bloom agreed.	 58.05983936138577
Has the laugh at him now.	 98.56403117884157
He looked down at the boots he had blacked and polished. She had	 38.60980891795556
outlived him. Lost her husband. More dead for her than for me. One must	 114.56999896418952
outlive the other. Wise men say. There are more women than men in the	 62.9061269022041
world. Condole with her. Your terrible loss. I hope you’ll soon follow	 91.05632347784307
him. For Hindu widows only. She would marry another. Him? No. Yet who	 119.3414088623239
knows after. Widowhood not the thing since the old queen died. Drawn on	 80.67921048842499
a guncarriage. Victoria and Albert. Frogmore memorial mourning. But in	 77.00062625800204
the end she put a few violets in her bonnet. Vain in her heart of	 51.12628601508952
hearts. All for a shadow. Consort not even a king. Her son was the	 137.0571785283331
substance. Something new to hope for not like the past she wanted back,	 183.95950750481558
waiting. It never comes. One must go first: alone, under the ground:	 142.96581635105866
and lie no more in her warm bed.	 97.51014980815384
—How are you, Simon? Ned Lambert said softly, clasping hands. Haven’t	 38.56612479060697
seen you for a month of Sundays.	 66.27563598509914
—Never better. How are all in Cork’s own town?	 101.03306453157181
—I was down there for the Cork park races on Easter Monday, Ned Lambert	 53.51497019464589
said. Same old six and eightpence. Stopped with Dick Tivy.	 134.23770216061973
—And how is Dick, the solid man?	 68.1197942251838
—Nothing between himself and heaven, Ned Lambert answered.	 80.0569104353627
—By the holy Paul! Mr Dedalus said in subdued wonder. Dick Tivy bald?	 106.30611858235532
—Martin is going to get up a whip for the youngsters, Ned Lambert said,	 28.3072021805886
pointing ahead. A few bob a skull. Just to keep them going till the	 70.53471169015006
insurance is cleared up.	 288.73730413829486
—Yes, yes, Mr Dedalus said dubiously. Is that the eldest boy in front?	 24.84040780114438
—Yes, Ned Lambert said, with the wife’s brother. John Henry Menton is	 29.409503733265183
behind. He put down his name for a quid.	 65.67029371647409
—I’ll engage he did, Mr Dedalus said. I often told poor Paddy he ought	 52.863469401509384
to mind that job. John Henry is not the worst in the world.	 110.57605907005079
—How did he lose it? Ned Lambert asked. Liquor, what?	 30.466562426715445
—Many a good man’s fault, Mr Dedalus said with a sigh.	 44.19419294207067
They halted about the door of the mortuary chapel. Mr Bloom stood	 26.684948643714915
behind the boy with the wreath looking down at his sleekcombed hair and	 61.17250947694528
at the slender furrowed neck inside his brandnew collar. Poor boy! Was	 126.06439441183844
he there when the father? Both unconscious. Lighten up at the last	 80.52621753786902
moment and recognise for the last time. All he might have done. I owe	 59.714360772647574
three shillings to O’Grady. Would he understand? The mutes bore the	 69.64335747713793
coffin into the chapel. Which end is his head?	 150.0090425784922
After a moment he followed the others in, blinking in the screened	 52.653422398539
light. The coffin lay on its bier before the chancel, four tall yellow	 79.23408442321893
candles at its corners. Always in front of us. Corny Kelleher, laying a	 111.73530050627504
wreath at each fore corner, beckoned to the boy to kneel. The mourners	 105.16372337839651
knelt here and there in prayingdesks. Mr Bloom stood behind near the	 74.4409218035093
font and, when all had knelt, dropped carefully his unfolded newspaper	 134.84250805958683
from his pocket and knelt his right knee upon it. He fitted his black	 55.93629076457249
hat gently on his left knee and, holding its brim, bent over piously.	 78.61040817467732
A server bearing a brass bucket with something in it came out through a	 75.47503361941646
door. The whitesmocked priest came after him, tidying his stole with	 45.71596833537053
one hand, balancing with the other a little book against his toad’s	 42.6507031878842
belly. Who’ll read the book? I, said the rook.	 160.40709599317458
They halted by the bier and the priest began to read out of his book	 27.308447063104996
with a fluent croak.	 10.272595751323685
Father Coffey. I knew his name was like a coffin. _Dominenamine._ Bully	 48.30771745642442
about the muzzle he looks. Bosses the show. Muscular christian. Woe	 73.53485103571782
betide anyone that looks crooked at him: priest. Thou art Peter. Burst	 206.34747047933885
sideways like a sheep in clover Dedalus says he will. With a belly on	 179.83487948734216
him like a poisoned pup. Most amusing expressions that man finds. Hhhn:	 39.056634500144234
burst sideways.	 4055.5004317627972
_—Non intres in judicium cum servo tuo, Domine._	 13.022572218386902
Makes them feel more important to be prayed over in Latin. Requiem	 89.61583610494127
mass. Crape weepers. Blackedged notepaper. Your name on the altarlist.	 33.5525693578281
Chilly place this. Want to feed well, sitting in there all the morning	 142.92506281184814
in the gloom kicking his heels waiting for the next please. Eyes of a	 77.58231407408448
toad too. What swells him up that way? Molly gets swelled after	 137.53993891547117
cabbage. Air of the place maybe. Looks full up of bad gas. Must be an	 120.67895402140891
infernal lot of bad gas round the place. Butchers, for instance: they	 41.38683023844214
get like raw beefsteaks. Who was telling me? Mervyn Browne. Down in the	 59.024150933206776
vaults of saint Werburgh’s lovely old organ hundred and fifty they have	 105.52047522191855
to bore a hole in the coffins sometimes to let out the bad gas and burn	 52.383084308977
it. Out it rushes: blue. One whiff of that and you’re a goner.	 95.44972695029135
My kneecap is hurting me. Ow. That’s better.	 91.462682919638
The priest took a stick with a knob at the end of it out of the boy’s	 32.788180258722385
bucket and shook it over the coffin. Then he walked to the other end	 79.45770523686033
and shook it again. Then he came back and put it back in the bucket. As	 39.11636370590551
you were before you rested. It’s all written down: he has to do it.	 75.97457000315458
_—Et ne nos inducas in tentationem._	 27.91332723020868
The server piped the answers in the treble. I often thought it would be	 51.58442749134722
better to have boy servants. Up to fifteen or so. After that, of course	 120.68525522810728
Holy water that was, I expect. Shaking sleep out of it. He must be fed	 65.75580073762173
up with that job, shaking that thing over all the corpses they trot up.	 59.49328700690192
What harm if he could see what he was shaking it over. Every mortal day	 41.39252942641709
a fresh batch: middleaged men, old women, children, women dead in	 115.87719292825672
childbirth, men with beards, baldheaded businessmen, consumptive girls	 32.53757825348031
with little sparrows’ breasts. All the year round he prayed the same	 75.9397220194809
thing over them all and shook water on top of them: sleep. On Dignam	 133.89601919149888
now.	 813.325939680297
_—In paradisum._	 25.877283914292452
Said he was going to paradise or is in paradise. Says that over	 82.90135531460632
everybody. Tiresome kind of a job. But he has to say something.	 83.51831730402442
The priest closed his book and went off, followed by the server. Corny	 52.975449184834815
Kelleher opened the sidedoors and the gravediggers came in, hoisted the	 51.24375350190626
coffin again, carried it out and shoved it on their cart. Corny	 82.38237545181147
Kelleher gave one wreath to the boy and one to the brother-in-law. All	 134.14596675483276
followed them out of the sidedoors into the mild grey air. Mr Bloom	 49.48203221205822
came last folding his paper again into his pocket. He gazed gravely at	 79.05362730074478
the ground till the coffincart wheeled off to the left. The metal	 69.24935257747205
wheels ground the gravel with a sharp grating cry and the pack of blunt	 34.2038224094044
boots followed the trundled barrow along a lane of sepulchres.	 70.57939224254918
The ree the ra the ree the ra the roo. Lord, I mustn’t lilt here.	 81.17788405675681
—The O’Connell circle, Mr Dedalus said about him.	 52.60364283878317
Mr Power’s soft eyes went up to the apex of the lofty cone.	 18.698898663992534
—He’s at rest, he said, in the middle of his people, old Dan O’. But	 75.24215949829993
his heart is buried in Rome. How many broken hearts are buried here,	 61.517371721713815
Simon!	 6665.955645642782
—Her grave is over there, Jack, Mr Dedalus said. I’ll soon be stretched	 60.59398043625918
beside her. Let Him take me whenever He likes.	 55.368420937663025
Breaking down, he began to weep to himself quietly, stumbling a little	 83.85089018324945
in his walk. Mr Power took his arm.	 43.61779471051911
—She’s better where she is, he said kindly.	 76.30415022503578
—I suppose so, Mr Dedalus said with a weak gasp. I suppose she is in	 27.819597616061678
heaven if there is a heaven.	 310.51481526804463
Corny Kelleher stepped aside from his rank and allowed the mourners to	 54.745120364689484
plod by.	 22.249992977439717
—Sad occasions, Mr Kernan began politely.	 81.25751115900385
Mr Bloom closed his eyes and sadly twice bowed his head.	 39.65665914174522
—The others are putting on their hats, Mr Kernan said. I suppose we can	 63.56914684341372
do so too. We are the last. This cemetery is a treacherous place.	 120.50318095069234
They covered their heads.	 233.40948347042936
—The reverend gentleman read the service too quickly, don’t you think?	 92.10474587489968
Mr Kernan said with reproof.	 25.908980605855277
Mr Bloom nodded gravely looking in the quick bloodshot eyes. Secret	 55.22601554427215
eyes, secretsearching. Mason, I think: not sure. Beside him again. We	 85.94273977134996
are the last. In the same boat. Hope he’ll say something else.	 64.18951706076206
Mr Kernan added:	 38.14367927893363
—The service of the Irish church used in Mount Jerome is simpler, more	 106.04084693510534
impressive I must say.	 33.31001043575683
Mr Bloom gave prudent assent. The language of course was another thing.	 49.456563321663666
Mr Kernan said with solemnity:	 25.908980605855277
—_I am the resurrection and the life_. That touches a man’s inmost	 32.505568099133754
heart.	 1482.469507881094
—It does, Mr Bloom said.	 36.05135430822263
Your heart perhaps but what price the fellow in the six feet by two	 122.86095035788789
with his toes to the daisies? No touching that. Seat of the affections.	 26.452624439173903
Broken heart. A pump after all, pumping thousands of gallons of blood	 89.28350013248469
every day. One fine day it gets bunged up: and there you are. Lots of	 63.83567424409284
them lying around here: lungs, hearts, livers. Old rusty pumps: damn	 172.63704134396085
the thing else. The resurrection and the life. Once you are dead you	 47.995905695625886
are dead. That last day idea. Knocking them all up out of their graves.	 85.01409347203335
Come forth, Lazarus! And he came fifth and lost the job. Get up! Last	 79.86013921480946
day! Then every fellow mousing around for his liver and his lights and	 93.55601814698255
the rest of his traps. Find damn all of himself that morning.	 79.66711868895005
Pennyweight of powder in a skull. Twelve grammes one pennyweight. Troy	 49.23632056162623
measure.	 12565.164778433977
Corny Kelleher fell into step at their side.	 88.44958912031944
—Everything went off A1, he said. What?	 93.2011475593196
He looked on them from his drawling eye. Policeman’s shoulders. With	 57.32849934015963
your tooraloom tooraloom.	 43.101804990616834
—As it should be, Mr Kernan said.	 32.1518698077867
—What? Eh? Corny Kelleher said.	 37.318499287141684
Mr Kernan assured him.	 40.00887653027337
—Who is that chap behind with Tom Kernan? John Henry Menton asked. I	 43.77134249358503
know his face.	 189.98807604450974
Ned Lambert glanced back.	 47.28297665749943
—Bloom, he said, Madame Marion Tweedy that was, is, I mean, the	 92.10618455704574
soprano. She’s his wife.	 107.58993566861723
—O, to be sure, John Henry Menton said. I haven’t seen her for some	 41.85939170220587
time. She was a finelooking woman. I danced with her, wait, fifteen	 69.32975662615576
seventeen golden years ago, at Mat Dillon’s in Roundtown. And a good	 44.74918888575304
armful she was.	 24.831553373374682
He looked behind through the others.	 109.77661042054207
—What is he? he asked. What does he do? Wasn’t he in the stationery	 44.94634436795596
line? I fell foul of him one evening, I remember, at bowls.	 173.31190364443106
Ned Lambert smiled.	 94.80298580857468
—Yes, he was, he said, in Wisdom Hely’s. A traveller for blottingpaper.	 34.85729029854842
—In God’s name, John Henry Menton said, what did she marry a coon like	 25.072238768364095
that for? She had plenty of game in her then.	 113.90734962672529
—Has still, Ned Lambert said. He does some canvassing for ads.	 51.640756622501314
John Henry Menton’s large eyes stared ahead.	 38.97335009715672
The barrow turned into a side lane. A portly man, ambushed among the	 41.99615896947865
grasses, raised his hat in homage. The gravediggers touched their caps.	 50.311969391642876
—John O’Connell, Mr Power said pleased. He never forgets a friend.	 57.52018735527173
Mr O’Connell shook all their hands in silence. Mr Dedalus said:	 60.42146410391397
—I am come to pay you another visit.	 93.61325641872922
—My dear Simon, the caretaker answered in a low voice. I don’t want	 56.04400698237415
your custom at all.	 74.56012458860818
Saluting Ned Lambert and John Henry Menton he walked on at Martin	 112.66564073309235
Cunningham’s side puzzling two long keys at his back.	 58.80785079746691
—Did you hear that one, he asked them, about Mulcahy from the Coombe?	 57.555550231044485
—I did not, Martin Cunningham said.	 17.38164957274196
They bent their silk hats in concert and Hynes inclined his ear. The	 116.50919948463397
caretaker hung his thumbs in the loops of his gold watchchain and spoke	 45.68877636745334
in a discreet tone to their vacant smiles.	 45.4002746967035
—They tell the story, he said, that two drunks came out here one foggy	 97.58923579131972
evening to look for the grave of a friend of theirs. They asked for	 79.46659540122596
Mulcahy from the Coombe and were told where he was buried. After	 73.8010768569662
traipsing about in the fog they found the grave sure enough. One of the	 82.83852463207494
drunks spelt out the name: Terence Mulcahy. The other drunk was	 37.06000508132824
blinking up at a statue of Our Saviour the widow had got put up.	 124.34111514536697
The caretaker blinked up at one of the sepulchres they passed. He	 48.14785970933255
resumed:	 4.608171674364364
—And, after blinking up at the sacred figure, _Not a bloody bit like	 67.48245175408904
the man_, says he. _That’s not Mulcahy_, says he, _whoever done it_.	 55.595321683679344
Rewarded by smiles he fell back and spoke with Corny Kelleher,	 48.53544297268995
accepting the dockets given him, turning them over and scanning them as	 53.64277391465721
he walked.	 40.36206349921228
—That’s all done with a purpose, Martin Cunningham explained to Hynes.	 60.669468920901146
—I know, Hynes said. I know that.	 26.740847268302776
—To cheer a fellow up, Martin Cunningham said. It’s pure	 86.98354224206501
goodheartedness: damn the thing else.	 59.26925603129271
Mr Bloom admired the caretaker’s prosperous bulk. All want to be on	 21.213974864142333
good terms with him. Decent fellow, John O’Connell, real good sort.	 127.09411542160744
Keys: like Keyes’s ad: no fear of anyone getting out. No passout	 136.43648972399265
checks. _Habeas corpus_. I must see about that ad after the funeral.	 58.07809186171085
Did I write Ballsbridge on the envelope I took to cover when she	 81.94395500434571
disturbed me writing to Martha? Hope it’s not chucked in the dead	 69.31350300141717
letter office. Be the better of a shave. Grey sprouting beard. That’s	 124.11866738610588
the first sign when the hairs come out grey. And temper getting cross.	 120.56191902573548
Silver threads among the grey. Fancy being his wife. Wonder he had the	 82.14425517982374
gumption to propose to any girl. Come out and live in the graveyard.	 44.09838909332509
Dangle that before her. It might thrill her first. Courting death.	 105.17924329153442
Shades of night hovering here with all the dead stretched about. The	 75.04506140018951
shadows of the tombs when churchyards yawn and Daniel O’Connell must be	 67.59834523082792
a descendant I suppose who is this used to say he was a queer breedy	 37.200147678607394
man great catholic all the same like a big giant in the dark. Will o’	 64.74453012504748
the wisp. Gas of graves. Want to keep her mind off it to conceive at	 46.97628015621684
all. Women especially are so touchy. Tell her a ghost story in bed to	 75.06703158963123
make her sleep. Have you ever seen a ghost? Well, I have. It was a	 58.644221946605754
pitchdark night. The clock was on the stroke of twelve. Still they’d	 129.8261970394341
kiss all right if properly keyed up. Whores in Turkish graveyards.	 80.11841091437464
Learn anything if taken young. You might pick up a young widow here.	 143.2422057161273
Men like that. Love among the tombstones. Romeo. Spice of pleasure. In	 46.82343563183952
the midst of death we are in life. Both ends meet. Tantalising for the	 71.31162602617295
poor dead. Smell of grilled beefsteaks to the starving. Gnawing their	 32.40753203085038
vitals. Desire to grig people. Molly wanting to do it at the window.	 79.31642416640781
Eight children he has anyway.	 118.02365925909913
He has seen a fair share go under in his time, lying around him field	 84.88096603707771
after field. Holy fields. More room if they buried them standing.	 228.4951692887862
Sitting or kneeling you couldn’t. Standing? His head might come up some	 158.43334924955974
day above ground in a landslip with his hand pointing. All honeycombed	 45.87427827467094
the ground must be: oblong cells. And very neat he keeps it too: trim	 51.64867851711974
grass and edgings. His garden Major Gamble calls Mount Jerome. Well, so	 104.78865199800249
it is. Ought to be flowers of sleep. Chinese cemeteries with giant	 35.100871527548875
poppies growing produce the best opium Mastiansky told me. The Botanic	 57.330045800512025
Gardens are just over there. It’s the blood sinking in the earth gives	 107.30031653317027
new life. Same idea those jews they said killed the christian boy.	 115.0982064949461
Every man his price. Well preserved fat corpse, gentleman, epicure,	 211.5081904359623
invaluable for fruit garden. A bargain. By carcass of William	 70.29720005156052
Wilkinson, auditor and accountant, lately deceased, three pounds	 32.741240905817214
thirteen and six. With thanks.	 241.75069214542071
I daresay the soil would be quite fat with corpsemanure, bones, flesh,	 155.0774799244589
nails. Charnelhouses. Dreadful. Turning green and pink decomposing. Rot	 125.04507563620794
quick in damp earth. The lean old ones tougher. Then a kind of a	 126.8785665300512
tallowy kind of a cheesy. Then begin to get black, black treacle oozing	 39.57679599341655
out of them. Then dried up. Deathmoths. Of course the cells or whatever	 48.33993533835754
they are go on living. Changing about. Live for ever practically.	 95.9767163664337
Nothing to feed on feed on themselves.	 196.11002866207573
But they must breed a devil of a lot of maggots. Soil must be simply	 61.658409163244194
swirling with them. Your head it simply swurls. Those pretty little	 93.9775396733491
seaside gurls. He looks cheerful enough over it. Gives him a sense of	 134.37281299891455
power seeing all the others go under first. Wonder how he looks at	 115.41023828421643
life. Cracking his jokes too: warms the cockles of his heart. The one	 50.26784790285733
about the bulletin. Spurgeon went to heaven 4 a.m. this morning. 11	 77.47882496768976
p.m. (closing time). Not arrived yet. Peter. The dead themselves the	 160.9460551638915
men anyhow would like to hear an odd joke or the women to know what’s	 98.07731860771933
in fashion. A juicy pear or ladies’ punch, hot, strong and sweet. Keep	 109.697731917644
out the damp. You must laugh sometimes so better do it that way.	 133.90857095927535
Gravediggers in _Hamlet_. Shows the profound knowledge of the human	 80.44885019915334
heart. Daren’t joke about the dead for two years at least. _De mortuis	 78.87825511404557
nil nisi prius_. Go out of mourning first. Hard to imagine his funeral.	 71.7065557611292
Seems a sort of a joke. Read your own obituary notice they say you live	 160.98817064852557
longer. Gives you second wind. New lease of life.	 307.5517213330153
—How many have you for tomorrow? the caretaker asked.	 67.14413837320217
—Two, Corny Kelleher said. Half ten and eleven.	 149.02786454590904
The caretaker put the papers in his pocket. The barrow had ceased to	 60.98462836079165
trundle. The mourners split and moved to each side of the hole,	 46.33427493318872
stepping with care round the graves. The gravediggers bore the coffin	 108.11278023749135
and set its nose on the brink, looping the bands round it.	 34.32134881839455
Burying him. We come to bury Cæsar. His ides of March or June. He	 73.96839920334321
doesn’t know who is here nor care. Now who is that lankylooking galoot	 53.20534156342334
over there in the macintosh? Now who is he I’d like to know? Now I’d	 68.45388361550899
give a trifle to know who he is. Always someone turns up you never	 85.30824146235385
dreamt of. A fellow could live on his lonesome all his life. Yes, he	 51.09527442565885
could. Still he’d have to get someone to sod him after he died though	 80.82247863164463
he could dig his own grave. We all do. Only man buries. No, ants too.	 94.43324720052838
First thing strikes anybody. Bury the dead. Say Robinson Crusoe was	 59.48783810880024
true to life. Well then Friday buried him. Every Friday buries a	 114.80451221182105
Thursday if you come to look at it.	 51.81074634050092
O, poor Robinson Crusoe!	 41.40482942092823
How could you possibly do so?	 76.75565360623784
Poor Dignam! His last lie on the earth in his box. When you think of	 72.81908193411222
them all it does seem a waste of wood. All gnawed through. They could	 126.98629570474368
invent a handsome bier with a kind of panel sliding, let it down that	 94.08597888969001
way. Ay but they might object to be buried out of another fellow’s.	 47.99856446839241
They’re so particular. Lay me in my native earth. Bit of clay from the	 118.65971436151905
holy land. Only a mother and deadborn child ever buried in the one	 108.65388273551254
coffin. I see what it means. I see. To protect him as long as possible	 42.71340937866116
even in the earth. The Irishman’s house is his coffin. Embalming in	 61.28794336505103
catacombs, mummies the same idea.	 27.337511410458173
Mr Bloom stood far back, his hat in his hand, counting the bared heads.	 28.08692037325576
Twelve. I’m thirteen. No. The chap in the macintosh is thirteen.	 143.1220419044572
Death’s number. Where the deuce did he pop out of? He wasn’t in the	 52.73735635345981
chapel, that I’ll swear. Silly superstition that about thirteen.	 251.75327644459145
Nice soft tweed Ned Lambert has in that suit. Tinge of purple. I had	 80.00513389635279
one like that when we lived in Lombard street west. Dressy fellow he	 34.095988168774525
was once. Used to change three suits in the day. Must get that grey	 83.39294533081515
suit of mine turned by Mesias. Hello. It’s dyed. His wife I forgot he’s	 144.1828438687319
not married or his landlady ought to have picked out those threads for	 65.85176152191387
him.	 330.5397417229756
The coffin dived out of sight, eased down by the men straddled on the	 39.176587404811215
gravetrestles. They struggled up and out: and all uncovered. Twenty.	 60.569692528102195
Pause.	 4.608171674364364
If we were all suddenly somebody else.	 37.93416129152664
Far away a donkey brayed. Rain. No such ass. Never see a dead one, they	 100.37432113103456
say. Shame of death. They hide. Also poor papa went away.	 108.75725810841094
Gentle sweet air blew round the bared heads in a whisper. Whisper. The	 89.50385919541961
boy by the gravehead held his wreath with both hands staring quietly in	 75.15074368568392
the black open space. Mr Bloom moved behind the portly kindly	 89.12007492971114
caretaker. Wellcut frockcoat. Weighing them up perhaps to see which	 145.348552021297
will go next. Well, it is a long rest. Feel no more. It’s the moment	 92.51475639518604
you feel. Must be damned unpleasant. Can’t believe it at first. Mistake	 75.40204089876906
must be: someone else. Try the house opposite. Wait, I wanted to. I	 49.24594957425812
haven’t yet. Then darkened deathchamber. Light they want. Whispering	 391.7938353056059
around you. Would you like to see a priest? Then rambling and	 59.93938165048451
wandering. Delirium all you hid all your life. The death struggle. His	 131.67653400333722
sleep is not natural. Press his lower eyelid. Watching is his nose	 222.2135367836899
pointed is his jaw sinking are the soles of his feet yellow. Pull the	 96.6166094078762
pillow away and finish it off on the floor since he’s doomed. Devil in	 126.54014134159722
that picture of sinner’s death showing him a woman. Dying to embrace	 75.32462771820475
her in his shirt. Last act of _Lucia. Shall I nevermore behold thee_?	 93.2042960354894
Bam! He expires. Gone at last. People talk about you a bit: forget you.	 50.06140665489691
Don’t forget to pray for him. Remember him in your prayers. Even	 75.16346241273824
Parnell. Ivy day dying out. Then they follow: dropping into a hole, one	 149.65189037932768
after the other.	 87.83860291976603
We are praying now for the repose of his soul. Hoping you’re well and	 43.81851281567248
not in hell. Nice change of air. Out of the fryingpan of life into the	 63.92599110269155
fire of purgatory.	 73.35524823389444
Does he ever think of the hole waiting for himself? They say you do	 61.7113148845104
when you shiver in the sun. Someone walking over it. Callboy’s warning.	 69.43196103136358
Near you. Mine over there towards Finglas, the plot I bought. Mamma,	 123.90186907720444
poor mamma, and little Rudy.	 50.21923991700224
The gravediggers took up their spades and flung heavy clods of clay in	 71.90846951141717
on the coffin. Mr Bloom turned away his face. And if he was alive all	 35.63790999191107
the time? Whew! By jingo, that would be awful! No, no: he is dead, of	 43.54188197517135
course. Of course he is dead. Monday he died. They ought to have some	 34.57262067341689
law to pierce the heart and make sure or an electric clock or a	 86.7279367963686
telephone in the coffin and some kind of a canvas airhole. Flag of	 37.20141586923677
distress. Three days. Rather long to keep them in summer. Just as well	 92.35313775227216
to get shut of them as soon as you are sure there’s no.	 38.2444887663535
The clay fell softer. Begin to be forgotten. Out of sight, out of mind.	 81.7772625374057
The caretaker moved away a few paces and put on his hat. Had enough of	 28.739189457049314
it. The mourners took heart of grace, one by one, covering themselves	 163.55311134508528
without show. Mr Bloom put on his hat and saw the portly figure make	 51.86849549480407
its way deftly through the maze of graves. Quietly, sure of his ground,	 61.43601919067401
he traversed the dismal fields.	 26.711547409873237
Hynes jotting down something in his notebook. Ah, the names. But he	 106.92536262196133
knows them all. No: coming to me.	 165.02588653284508
—I am just taking the names, Hynes said below his breath. What is your	 86.98683660458006
christian name? I’m not sure.	 104.54079931038177
—L, Mr Bloom said. Leopold. And you might put down M’Coy’s name too. He	 81.08620685955816
asked me to.	 103.67273601292324
—Charley, Hynes said writing. I know. He was on the _Freeman_ once.	 73.89910035194346
So he was before he got the job in the morgue under Louis Byrne. Good	 86.37889945545504
idea a postmortem for doctors. Find out what they imagine they know. He	 123.55957425090773
died of a Tuesday. Got the run. Levanted with the cash of a few ads.	 49.90262433964199
Charley, you’re my darling. That was why he asked me to. O well, does	 84.86849951680718
no harm. I saw to that, M’Coy. Thanks, old chap: much obliged. Leave	 120.90345174968587
him under an obligation: costs nothing.	 106.37518025298627
—And tell us, Hynes said, do you know that fellow in the, fellow was	 33.07204537103045
over there in the...	 54.07709683523123
He looked around.	 61.8399134361914
—Macintosh. Yes, I saw him, Mr Bloom said. Where is he now?	 48.86297322291457
—M’Intosh, Hynes said scribbling. I don’t know who he is. Is that his	 37.776819784320594
name?	 1099.0983667900869
He moved away, looking about him.	 59.954542600873125
—No, Mr Bloom began, turning and stopping. I say, Hynes!	 117.047248911325
Didn’t hear. What? Where has he disappeared to? Not a sign. Well of all	 105.39799955760525
the. Has anybody here seen? Kay ee double ell. Become invisible. Good	 139.27385421523667
Lord, what became of him?	 233.92914569013533
A seventh gravedigger came beside Mr Bloom to take up an idle spade.	 57.19224403997277
—O, excuse me!	 42.37663702819156
He stepped aside nimbly.	 23.291459286634556
Clay, brown, damp, began to be seen in the hole. It rose. Nearly over.	 114.00962607804134
A mound of damp clods rose more, rose, and the gravediggers rested	 52.56954750424679
their spades. All uncovered again for a few instants. The boy propped	 91.95894970386492
his wreath against a corner: the brother-in-law his on a lump. The	 152.5032086010415
gravediggers put on their caps and carried their earthy spades towards	 82.88627982030347
the barrow. Then knocked the blades lightly on the turf: clean. One	 90.13443303516367
bent to pluck from the haft a long tuft of grass. One, leaving his	 65.10500285850172
mates, walked slowly on with shouldered weapon, its blade blueglancing.	 89.79731633832091
Silently at the gravehead another coiled the coffinband. His navelcord.	 56.26664893999507
The brother-in-law, turning away, placed something in his free hand.	 69.46213301975317
Thanks in silence. Sorry, sir: trouble. Headshake. I know that. For	 74.0272926455286
yourselves just.	 101.33425343375232
The mourners moved away slowly without aim, by devious paths, staying	 29.92098870021678
at whiles to read a name on a tomb.	 45.196447941363104
—Let us go round by the chief’s grave, Hynes said. We have time.	 33.45641596107154
—Let us, Mr Power said.	 24.469594743593074
They turned to the right, following their slow thoughts. With awe Mr	 80.35587151729776
Power’s blank voice spoke:	 184.3166545217468
—Some say he is not in that grave at all. That the coffin was filled	 85.07780991444457
with stones. That one day he will come again.	 74.06762644756527
Hynes shook his head.	 62.762501897916536
—Parnell will never come again, he said. He’s there, all that was	 56.784198297850146
mortal of him. Peace to his ashes.	 150.39266492655017
Mr Bloom walked unheeded along his grove by saddened angels, crosses,	 32.426424074818605
broken pillars, family vaults, stone hopes praying with upcast eyes,	 95.53104992368434
old Ireland’s hearts and hands. More sensible to spend the money on	 111.50129030447661
some charity for the living. Pray for the repose of the soul of. Does	 42.09210239240559
anybody really? Plant him and have done with him. Like down a	 84.17876163123832
coalshoot. Then lump them together to save time. All souls’ day.	 128.55833581380824
Twentyseventh I’ll be at his grave. Ten shillings for the gardener. He	 48.304939804840814
keeps it free of weeds. Old man himself. Bent down double with his	 187.7750881954238
shears clipping. Near death’s door. Who passed away. Who departed this	 210.6748186696023
life. As if they did it of their own accord. Got the shove, all of	 77.44646449813541
them. Who kicked the bucket. More interesting if they told you what	 116.96245555163695
they were. So and So, wheelwright. I travelled for cork lino. I paid	 55.12852041551255
five shillings in the pound. Or a woman’s with her saucepan. I cooked	 61.10863241170743
good Irish stew. Eulogy in a country churchyard it ought to be that	 50.05502045855983
poem of whose is it Wordsworth or Thomas Campbell. Entered into rest	 118.67118707817447
the protestants put it. Old Dr Murren’s. The great physician called him	 66.30889169818457
home. Well it’s God’s acre for them. Nice country residence. Newly	 78.64696555343623
plastered and painted. Ideal spot to have a quiet smoke and read the	 42.23466631030124
_Church Times._ Marriage ads they never try to beautify. Rusty wreaths	 178.58335496317883
hung on knobs, garlands of bronzefoil. Better value that for the money.	 75.78830541240157
Still, the flowers are more poetical. The other gets rather tiresome,	 80.02460806918386
never withering. Expresses nothing. Immortelles.	 91.97602559487812
A bird sat tamely perched on a poplar branch. Like stuffed. Like the	 55.95893038054403
wedding present alderman Hooper gave us. Hoo! Not a budge out of him.	 78.45063445945166
Knows there are no catapults to let fly at him. Dead animal even	 93.36660168952513
sadder. Silly-Milly burying the little dead bird in the kitchen	 37.78093633063295
matchbox, a daisychain and bits of broken chainies on the grave.	 42.087395031695465
The Sacred Heart that is: showing it. Heart on his sleeve. Ought to be	 48.19617781845944
sideways and red it should be painted like a real heart. Ireland was	 159.68167606907554
dedicated to it or whatever that. Seems anything but pleased. Why this	 191.5020066863278
infliction? Would birds come then and peck like the boy with the basket	 118.45981143293817
of fruit but he said no because they ought to have been afraid of the	 38.869591742318796
boy. Apollo that was.	 84.68823661616963
How many! All these here once walked round Dublin. Faithful departed.	 139.83030305417944
As you are now so once were we.	 90.82765475575688
Besides how could you remember everybody? Eyes, walk, voice. Well, the	 191.87589288919241
voice, yes: gramophone. Have a gramophone in every grave or keep it in	 112.29315262830414
the house. After dinner on a Sunday. Put on poor old greatgrandfather.	 79.62592046988908
Kraahraark! Hellohellohello amawfullyglad kraark awfullygladaseeagain	 3.933542382544028
hellohello amawf krpthsth. Remind you of the voice like the photograph	 34.92590058096363
reminds you of the face. Otherwise you couldn’t remember the face after	 87.20911660892293
fifteen years, say. For instance who? For instance some fellow that	 284.51642586535894
died when I was in Wisdom Hely’s.	 54.33712625242979
Rtststr! A rattle of pebbles. Wait. Stop!	 109.85691764524483
He looked down intently into a stone crypt. Some animal. Wait. There he	 67.35731836213819
goes.	 6394.461112828948
An obese grey rat toddled along the side of the crypt, moving the	 40.34355669928146
pebbles. An old stager: greatgrandfather: he knows the ropes. The grey	 87.94194170363313
alive crushed itself in under the plinth, wriggled itself in under it.	 109.04100669230719
Good hidingplace for treasure.	 148.24709917439563
Who lives there? Are laid the remains of Robert Emery. Robert Emmet was	 65.17680797632988
buried here by torchlight, wasn’t he? Making his rounds.	 163.25568579554965
Tail gone now.	 467.868288526941
One of those chaps would make short work of a fellow. Pick the bones	 144.82002291206493
clean no matter who it was. Ordinary meat for them. A corpse is meat	 178.84826739368722
gone bad. Well and what’s cheese? Corpse of milk. I read in that	 129.78913836824267
_Voyages in China_ that the Chinese say a white man smells like a	 59.0753504187312
corpse. Cremation better. Priests dead against it. Devilling for the	 72.3996240683871
other firm. Wholesale burners and Dutch oven dealers. Time of the	 18.602549424179013
plague. Quicklime feverpits to eat them. Lethal chamber. Ashes to	 120.18224039447063
ashes. Or bury at sea. Where is that Parsee tower of silence? Eaten by	 157.5699733404682
birds. Earth, fire, water. Drowning they say is the pleasantest. See	 140.23825206687
your whole life in a flash. But being brought back to life no. Can’t	 105.15206532086417
bury in the air however. Out of a flying machine. Wonder does the news	 81.331000527186
go about whenever a fresh one is let down. Underground communication.	 164.4523454203335
We learned that from them. Wouldn’t be surprised. Regular square feed	 167.52829509868172
for them. Flies come before he’s well dead. Got wind of Dignam. They	 264.42861385944553
wouldn’t care about the smell of it. Saltwhite crumbling mush of	 26.661975251403895
corpse: smell, taste like raw white turnips.	 249.35801869616142
The gates glimmered in front: still open. Back to the world again.	 93.29988459702462
Enough of this place. Brings you a bit nearer every time. Last time I	 75.95134705451652
was here was Mrs Sinico’s funeral. Poor papa too. The love that kills.	 126.12258894803469
And even scraping up the earth at night with a lantern like that case I	 54.28849769580974
read of to get at fresh buried females or even putrefied with running	 210.37086302321686
gravesores. Give you the creeps after a bit. I will appear to you after	 45.27081049044698
death. You will see my ghost after death. My ghost will haunt you after	 85.69724964774902
death. There is another world after death named hell. I do not like	 92.01988498290754
that other world she wrote. No more do I. Plenty to see and hear and	 74.90375637079119
feel yet. Feel live warm beings near you. Let them sleep in their	 160.20874073425085
maggoty beds. They are not going to get me this innings. Warm beds:	 69.08215409001113
warm fullblooded life.	 342.2029899073856
Martin Cunningham emerged from a sidepath, talking gravely.	 66.63736279382314
Solicitor, I think. I know his face. Menton, John Henry, solicitor,	 128.6942733314638
commissioner for oaths and affidavits. Dignam used to be in his office.	 30.97911155068187
Mat Dillon’s long ago. Jolly Mat. Convivial evenings. Cold fowl,	 82.8952699889864
cigars, the Tantalus glasses. Heart of gold really. Yes, Menton. Got	 112.19622133561373
his rag out that evening on the bowlinggreen because I sailed inside	 129.98813799666536
him. Pure fluke of mine: the bias. Why he took such a rooted dislike to	 69.43520427432011
me. Hate at first sight. Molly and Floey Dillon linked under the	 118.44084564106171
lilactree, laughing. Fellow always like that, mortified if women are	 130.5398328064809
by.	 343.92614956489206
Got a dinge in the side of his hat. Carriage probably.	 36.52628680806321
—Excuse me, sir, Mr Bloom said beside them.	 29.527873070068793
They stopped.	 238.370955617251
—Your hat is a little crushed, Mr Bloom said pointing.	 59.88085627662612
John Henry Menton stared at him for an instant without moving.	 34.60987928819092

the nap with care on his coatsleeve. He clapped the hat on his head	 23.725443383308715
again.	 1025.9873088345048
—It’s all right now, Martin Cunningham said.	 23.24411052098415

—Thank you, he said shortly.	 21.367540294571597

IN THE HEART OF THE HIBERNIAN METROPOLIS	 11.270752988590706

WILLIAM BRAYDEN, ESQUIRE, OF OAKLANDS, SANDYMOUNT	 62.81480883457691
Red Murray touched Mr Bloom’s arm with the shears and whispered:	 88.15415044553477
—Brayden.	 4.608171674364364
Mr Bloom turned and saw the liveried porter raise his lettered cap as a	 32.284921647765856
stately figure entered between the newsboards of the _Weekly Freeman	 48.74197416601455
and National Press_ and the _Freeman’s Journal and National Press_.	 37.94023370108071
Dullthudding Guinness’s barrels. It passed statelily up the staircase,	 140.50600154921602

ascended each step: back. All his brains are in the nape of his neck,	 55.34802684608429
Simon Dedalus says. Welts of flesh behind on him. Fat folds of neck,	 204.12439671755482
fat, neck, fat, neck.	 157.4772050167456
—Don’t you think his face is like Our Saviour? Red Murray whispered.	 78.8162730256742
The door of Ruttledge’s office whispered: ee: cree. They always build	 50.594291127512854
one door opposite another for the wind to. Way in. Way out.	 112.07864525630211
Our Saviour: beardframed oval face: talking in the dusk. Mary, Martha.	 123.60109422577861

THE CROZIER AND THE PEN	 46.26464235919681
—His grace phoned down twice this morning, Red Murray said gravely.	 85.76219998230242
They watched the knees, legs, boots vanish. Neck.	 242.76653421442214
A telegram boy stepped in nimbly, threw an envelope on the counter and	 146.77226058335123
stepped off posthaste with a word:	 80.59025322535575
_—Freeman!_	 7790.460052842213
Mr Bloom said slowly:	 34.425586212359896
—Well, he is one of our saviours also.	 88.57331538066423
A meek smile accompanied him as he lifted the counterflap, as he passed	 30.81875960709346
in through a sidedoor and along the warm dark stairs and passage, along	 88.79095831731934
the now reverberating boards. But will he save the circulation?	 75.19477998952944
Thumping. Thumping.	 1011.3894538981172
He pushed in the glass swingdoor and entered, stepping over strewn	 45.05986653504853
packing paper. Through a lane of clanking drums he made his way towards	 64.31936746494688
Nannetti’s reading closet.	 72.92624914644267
WITH UNFEIGNED REGRET IT IS WE ANNOUNCE THE DISSOLUTION OF A MOST	 37.4037090518024
RESPECTED DUBLIN BURGESS	 39.857636109154136
Hynes here too: account of the funeral probably. Thumping. Thump. This	 82.3436224336059
morning the remains of the late Mr Patrick Dignam. Machines. Smash a	 70.8808617539431
man to atoms if they got him caught. Rule the world today. His	 98.06561399234897
machineries are pegging away too. Like these, got out of hand:	 151.86187316076405
fermenting. Working away, tearing away. And that old grey rat tearing	 94.717199782794
to get in.	 75.6869888185023
HOW A GREAT DAILY ORGAN IS TURNED OUT	 211.62204294603933
Mr Bloom halted behind the foreman’s spare body, admiring a glossy	 18.358560244601623
crown.	 3877.219656660332
Strange he never saw his real country. Ireland my country. Member for	 98.49256828362391
College green. He boomed that workaday worker tack for all it was	 32.195285611477146
worth. It’s the ads and side features sell a weekly, not the stale news	 236.52115830412097
in the official gazette. Queen Anne is dead. Published by authority in	 48.07534708475698
the year one thousand and. Demesne situate in the townland of	 26.011093430216164
Rosenallis, barony of Tinnahinch. To all whom it may concern schedule	 30.938692490269926
pursuant to statute showing return of number of mules and jennets	 36.19351907637374
exported from Ballina. Nature notes. Cartoons. Phil Blake’s weekly Pat	 45.07450352482986
and Bull story. Uncle Toby’s page for tiny tots. Country bumpkin’s	 142.36585424003542
queries. Dear Mr Editor, what is a good cure for flatulence? I’d like	 76.54976187901276
that part. Learn a lot teaching others. The personal note. M. A. P.	 263.6768922826927
Mainly all pictures. Shapely bathers on golden strand. World’s biggest	 73.23558504944141
balloon. Double marriage of sisters celebrated. Two bridegrooms	 81.99240550547502
laughing heartily at each other. Cuprani too, printer. More Irish than	 99.58519007729438
the Irish.	 68.37682921406459
The machines clanked in threefour time. Thump, thump, thump. Now if he	 33.858243702323676
got paralysed there and no-one knew how to stop them they’d clank on	 97.53958009481332
and on the same, print it over and over and up and back. Monkeydoodle	 65.03965413354693
the whole thing. Want a cool head.	 112.70198104537526
—Well, get it into the evening edition, councillor, Hynes said.	 98.8113294590709
Soon be calling him my lord mayor. Long John is backing him, they say.	 88.69457266330171

sheet and made a sign to a typesetter. He handed the sheet silently	 113.91138026457165
over the dirty glass screen.	 232.78041140031678
—Right: thanks, Hynes said moving off.	 90.10464694224373
Mr Bloom stood in his way.	 27.519578813661266

pointing backward with his thumb.	 189.16313543373624

Mr Bloom laid his cutting on Mr Nannetti’s desk.	 53.56285537136903

The foreman moved his pencil towards it.	 28.90678784832505

Maybe he understands what I.	 119.82118869593869
The foreman turned round to hear patiently and, lifting an elbow, began	 67.9851566045341
to scratch slowly in the armpit of his alpaca jacket.	 67.75077603241728

obedient reels feeding in huge webs of paper. Clank it. Clank it. Miles	 67.17750807462195

A DAYFATHER	 13.400948507362273
He walked on through the caseroom passing an old man, bowed,	 41.70414878803475
spectacled, aproned. Old Monks, the dayfather. Queer lot of stuff he	 51.36074619657277
must have put through his hands in his time: obituary notices, pubs’	 41.78577671182045
ads, speeches, divorce suits, found drowned. Nearing the end of his	 44.87092087708837
tether now. Sober serious man with a bit in the savingsbank I’d say.	 59.65551807556752
Wife a good cook and washer. Daughter working the machine in the	 91.82340734168363
parlour. Plain Jane, no damn nonsense.	 232.42722110395738
AND IT WAS THE FEAST OF THE PASSOVER	 17.227649665062824
He stayed in his walk to watch a typesetter neatly distributing type.	 44.92489504024755
Reads it backwards first. Quickly he does it. Must require some	 133.70359512972158
practice that. mangiD kcirtaP. Poor papa with his hagadah book, reading	 56.51023569627151
backwards with his finger to me. Pessach. Next year in Jerusalem. Dear,	 80.72014006985424
O dear! All that long business about that brought us out of the land of	 51.24597396206434
Egypt and into the house of bondage _alleluia. Shema Israel Adonai	 50.90687780034116
Elohenu_. No, that’s the other. Then the twelve brothers, Jacob’s sons.	 106.76164427715418
And then the lamb and the cat and the dog and the stick and the water	 63.08765232639381
and the butcher. And then the angel of death kills the butcher and he	 39.08559234325131
kills the ox and the dog kills the cat. Sounds a bit silly till you	 59.36674708777498
come to look into it well. Justice it means but it’s everybody eating	 101.27758537514535
everyone else. That’s what life is after all. How quickly he does that	 150.0689129705399
job. Practice makes perfect. Seems to see with his fingers.	 79.37063061796145
Mr Bloom passed on out of the clanking noises through the gallery on to	 33.27840945130027
the landing. Now am I going to tram it out all the way and then catch	 62.410751949874005
him out perhaps. Better phone him up first. Number? Yes. Same as	 290.5119399066324
Citron’s house. Twentyeight. Twentyeight double four.	 119.39791277729462
ONLY ONCE MORE THAT SOAP	 181.72861777156555
He went down the house staircase. Who the deuce scrawled all over those	 39.06436394111918

smell there always is in those works. Lukewarm glue in Thom’s next door	 161.74691400240562
when I was there.	 49.847454928047384

ERIN, GREEN GEM OF THE SILVER SEA	 84.29037919311703

the dusty windowpane.	 78.32118522670552
Mr Dedalus, staring from the empty fireplace at Ned Lambert’s quizzing	 48.19376416444278
face, asked of it sourly:	 90.8069181520248
—Agonising Christ, wouldn’t it give you a heartburn on your arse?	 72.94715063728144
Ned Lambert, seated on the table, read on:	 31.777098338307763
—_Or again, note the meanderings of some purling rill as it babbles on	 42.44415948439315
its way, tho’ quarrelling with the stony obstacles, to the tumbling	 31.205242433990783
waters of Neptune’s blue domain, ’mid mossy banks, fanned by gentlest	 19.659352532210654
zephyrs, played on by the glorious sunlight or ’neath the shadows cast	 119.67306871584051
o’er its pensive bosom by the overarching leafage of the giants of the	 13.001974813720803
forest_. What about that, Simon? he asked over the fringe of his	 49.24371209419723
newspaper. How’s that for high?	 197.29427995007893
—Changing his drink, Mr Dedalus said.	 89.28969259880984
Ned Lambert, laughing, struck the newspaper on his knees, repeating:	 43.54137394309497

—And Xenophon looked upon Marathon, Mr Dedalus said, looking again on	 45.04293367025739

High falutin stuff. Bladderbags. Ned Lambert is taking a day off I see.	 102.5567374669665

Old Chatterton, the vicechancellor, is his granduncle or his	 32.08087256898922
greatgranduncle. Close on ninety they say. Subleader for his death	 63.46754805662534
written this long time perhaps. Living to spite them. Might go first	 138.13422802457833
himself. Johnny, make room for your uncle. The right honourable Hedges	 60.5627039499914
Eyre Chatterton. Daresay he writes him an odd shaky cheque or two on	 39.6065731268588
gale days. Windfall when he kicks out. Alleluia.	 48.25775005274391

all blows over. Hail fellow well met the next moment.	 83.79670619928858

WHAT WETHERUP SAID	 120.53230372466058

blowing.	 9669.252855420213
Lenehan began to paw the tissues up from the floor, grunting as he	 39.77917019546325
stooped twice.	 2264.622850874194
—Waiting for the racing special, sir, the newsboy said. It was Pat	 56.58745154696815
Farrell shoved me, sir.	 57.02735391801143
He pointed to two faces peering in round the doorframe.	 99.11317657345644
—Him, sir.	 398.86417828437226
—Out of this with you, professor MacHugh said gruffly.	 38.36349423895547
He hustled the boy out and banged the door to.	 48.29591272855766

—Continued on page six, column four.	 179.24669757633615

rooms?... Aha! I see... Right. I’ll catch him.	 77.71966501013723
A COLLISION ENSUES	 9.296616798493048
The bell whirred again as he rang off. He came in quickly and bumped	 111.49304489031351
against Lenehan who was struggling up with the second tissue.	 68.53139993383904

hurry.	 3129.8651959710423
—Knee, Lenehan said.	 332.78401358157373

—Sorry, Mr Bloom said.	 29.097866204645765

We are the boys of Wexford	 33.813582860380706
Who fought with heart and hand.	 202.14834233689174
EXIT BLOOM	 53.027287990421996

A STREET CORTÈGE	 127.43428374968818

walk. Small nines. Steal upon larks.	 133.31410446378476

feet past the fireplace to J. J. O’Molloy who placed the tissues in his	 42.49694784774114

gone?	 3074.575063198837

THE CALUMET OF PEACE	 27.699066306169705

promptly struck a match for them and lit their cigarettes in turn. J.	 129.58497246277125

declaimed in song, pointing sternly at professor MacHugh:	 67.74778379699246
’Twas rank and fame that tempted thee,	 78.71252418132089
’Twas empire charmed thy heart.	 102.98160814305082
The professor grinned, locking his long lips.	 39.71896085297467
—Eh? You bloody old Roman empire? Myles Crawford said.	 36.82438771793109
He took a cigarette from the open case. Lenehan, lighting it for him	 54.473018222207244
with quick grace, said:	 512.6734969593265
—Silence for my brandnew riddle!	 257.0500037021289
—_Imperium romanum_, J. J. O’Molloy said gently. It sounds nobler than	 31.797183713807023
British or Brixton. The word reminds one somehow of fat in the fire.	 112.75874431159129
Myles Crawford blew his first puff violently towards the ceiling.	 27.312227849414793
—That’s it, he said. We are the fat. You and I are the fat in the fire.	 77.6113013697786
We haven’t got the chance of a snowball in hell.	 64.41797515169344
THE GRANDEUR THAT WAS ROME	 35.33832741534625
—Wait a moment, professor MacHugh said, raising two quiet claws. We	 45.83656155270023
mustn’t be led away by words, by sounds of words. We think of Rome,	 92.44737512238753
imperial, imperious, imperative.	 4.206040932916629
He extended elocutionary arms from frayed stained shirtcuffs, pausing:	 50.7027901151955
—What was their civilisation? Vast, I allow: but vile. Cloacae: sewers.	 106.12794481898983
The Jews in the wilderness and on the mountaintop said: _It is meet to	 26.801109215430227
be here. Let us build an altar to Jehovah_. The Roman, like the	 85.32828604598097
Englishman who follows in his footsteps, brought to every new shore on	 170.4703449830524
which he set his foot (on our shore he never set it) only his cloacal	 53.538453118993814
obsession. He gazed about him in his toga and he said: _It is meet to	 29.481995078086737
be here. Let us construct a watercloset._	 67.89534159210002
—Which they accordingly did do, Lenehan said. Our old ancient	 111.23803247569774
ancestors, as we read in the first chapter of Guinness’s, were partial	 38.728029381580434
to the running stream.	 186.1754958468689
—They were nature’s gentlemen, J. J. O’Molloy murmured. But we have	 47.16552988411836
also Roman law.	 278.7713574522253
—And Pontius Pilate is its prophet, professor MacHugh responded.	 34.913618494794385
